comment.narrative: Indicador prioritario 1: Número de hectáreas establecidas para la conservación de Altos Valores de Conservación Indicador prioritario 2: Número de herramientas para conservación y monitoreo de Biodiversidad generadas y aplicadas Indicador prioritario 3: Número de contratos de compra concretados con instituciones públicas Indicador prioritario 4: Superficie certificada Indicador prioritario 5: Número de Certificaciones en Cadena de Custodia Indicador prioritario 6: Número de Alianzas productivas facilitadas por el proyecto

1. Se concluyeron dos estudios para la identifiación de Altos Valores de Conservación en Hidalgo (Ejido Chacalapa: 327 hectáreas; Ejido Nopalillo 829 hectáreas). Asimismo, se concluyeron 6 estudios Regionales de Biodiversidad, en los que se identifican prácticas regionales de conservación de biodiversidad, atributos AVC y especies en riesgo; los cuales abarcan más de 3.6 millones de hectáreas. 2. Se integró la “Caja de herramientas para integrar la conservación de la Biodiversidad en el Manejo Forestal”, la cual es el resultado de seis años de ejecución y sistematización del proyecto y contiene una recopilación de 9 de sus publicaciones, que actualmente funcionan como herramientas técnicas para la integración del tema de conservación de la biodiversidad en las actividades productivas. Las cajas de herramientas fueron distribuidas a más de 100 actores importantes en el sector forestal (prestadores de servicios técnicos, funcionarios, académicos, directores de centros de estudios, etc) 3. Se firmaron dos contratos de Compras Verdes de madera certificada; el primero entre la presidencia Municipal de Pihuamo, Jalisco, con Aserradero Barranca del Calabozo; y el segundo entre el Ayuntamiento de San juan Evangelista Analco, Oaxaca, con la empresa Industria Forestal Pueblos Mancomunados SPR de RL. 4. En este semestre se concretó la certificación de 42 predios, con una superficie de 294,879 hectáreas (12 predios con la certificación internacional FSC, con una superficie de 123,380 ha; 5 predios certificados bajo la NMX, con una superficie de 12,643 ha; 25 predios con Auditoría Técnica Preventiva, con una superficie de 158,856 ha).. De manera acumulada, se cuenta con 308 predios con certificado vigente en las áreas de atención del proyecto con una superficie de 1,992,446 hectáreas (67 predios con certificado internacional FSC: 832,852 ha; 127 predios con certificado nacional NMX: 849,775 ha; 114 predios con Auditoría Técnica Preventiva: 309,819 ha) 5. Se concretaron 12 certi

a Considering that some pieces of land reported during earlier periods have been subject to recertification processes which has entailed an adjustment to areas with high conservation values in some cases an exercise was undertaken to verify and update information on areas reported in the available support documents Additionally the information was confirmed by personnel of RACert During this exercise it was identified that some pieces of land were reported at different times thereby duplicating information Therefore adjustments were made
In this regard of the 37 baseline CFEs 34 have completed their studies to identify areas with high conservation values with a total area of 22738113 hectares ha Of these 34 CFEs two successfully completed their study in this period Comunidad Santiago Textitlán 1309 ha and the Foresters Union of ZapotecasChinantecas de la Sierra de Juárez de RI2629362 ha both in Oaxaca
Of the pieces of land set out on the baseline 28 are certified In this regard the HCV area on certified pieces of land is 196874477 ha
In addition to the baseline the studies concluded amount to 80 Through these the area identified with high conservation values is 313396 ha of the 80 pieces of land 34 are certified and have an HVC area of 5950109 ha Of the 72 pieces of land 39 concluded their studies in this period with an area of 91591 ha Of these 11 are certified and have a total HCV area of 2042724 ha
Of the 39 additional pieces of land that completed their study in this period 21 are in the Northern Region with 50297 ha six are in the Central Region with 778414 ha nine are in the East Central Region with an area of 181278 ha two pieces of land are in the Southern Region with 669726 and one is in the Southeastern Region with 1 of 25000 ha
In total there is a cumulative area of 540777 ha identified in the studies with high conservation value characteristics which means that 220 of the planned goal was met
b 91 of baseline CFEs have completed their HCV study 34 CFEs Of these two CFEs concluded their HCV study in 20142015
In addition to the baseline 80 studies have been concluded 34 of which were concluded during the 20142015 period
On a cumulative basis in the projects areas of focus there are 114 studies to identify high conservation value areas a number above the scheduled goal
c 114 CFEs have completed their studies to identify high conservation value areas which have been incorporated into their Forest Management Plans FMPs
Additionally 592 pieces of land are recorded that incorporate biodiversity criteria into their Forest Management Programs FMPs based on the Manual of Best Biodiversity Conservation Practices that the project produced in 2013 which has had an impact on an area of around 12 million ha Additionally with the CONAFORs support eight consultancies are in process of being hired to advise producers on incorporating biodiversity criteria into their FMPs on 720 pieces of land in the states of Chihuahua Durango Jalisco Michoacán Puebla Oaxaca Guerrero Campeche and Quintana Roo which amount to 11 million ha
On the other hand the project designed a base structure to conduct Regional Biodiversity Studies RBSs Currently there are 12 RBSs in Chihuahua and Durango in their final stage of being carried out They consider biodiversity conservation practices for sites stands and landscapes as well as the identification of high conservation value attributes in an area of 8 million ha
Likewise 131 Community Forest Enterprises CFEs were trained to prepare their Biological Monitoring and Habitat Quality Programs these tools allow them to obtain or maintain certification and provide information on the impact of productive activity on the piece of lands biodiversity

description.narrative: 2 Strengthened institutional capacity to support biodiversity conservation through certified community forestry

comment.narrative: Low nationalscale capacity to assist biodiversity mgmt in certified production forest

3 BD mgmt and monitoring tools adapted and in application
300 staff trained in certification and BD mgmt extension

An element that has contributed to the functioning of the project and achievement of its goals is the generation of knowledge products These tools serve to support producers and technical service providers in implementing practices that contribute to biodiversity conservation Additionally they are useful to public servants mainly of the CONAFOR and the SEMARNAT for giving opinions on forest management projects and support resources
In this regard the following four new knowledge products have also been developed during this period
1 Road Manual Techniques to Control el Sediment on Secondary Forest Roads
2 Forest Management Reserva Forestal Multifuncional El Manantial SC Concepts Conduct and Actions
3 Forest Habitat Characterization and Classification Guide
4 General guidelines to incorporate biodiversity conservation into FMPs for utilization of timber forest resources
The documents along with the Manual produced in 2013 have been published for consultation on the CONAFOR page httpwwwconaforgobmxwebtemasforestalesbiodiversidad Five new knowledge products have been created representing 166 of the planned goal
The HCV Identification Guide reported in the previous period is a document that considers a broad conceptual framework to identify High Conservation Values a process which needs to be more operational
Additionally other knowledge products are being developed which are expected to be completed no later than June 2016
b A crucial element in implementing actions promoted by the project has been capacity building among different forestry sector stakeholders In this regard the reporting period has been the one with the greatest number of training events and persons trained From June 2014 to July 2015 104 training events took place which 1782 people attended Of these people 16 are technical personnel from the CONAFOR 5 from the SEMARNAT 1 from the PROFEPA 15 from the CONABIO 05 from the CONANP 46 are Technical Service Providers 6 are from State Governments 14 are academics and 9 are from NGOs To date 1289 forest producers or CFE members have been trained
Of the people trained 24 now have knowledge of technical aspects and practices related to biodiversity conservation 26 have strengthened their forest management capacities 8 now have the technical capacities and knowledge to develop a biological monitoring system 1 have the technical capacities and knowledge to develop an HCV study 16 have knowledge of the countrys certification tools and 24 have received specialized consulting on the issue of competitiveness and markets
We highlight the 491 women who attended training events during this period and who represent 16 of the total persons who attended
Cumulatively 194 training events on the different mentioned topics have been recorded In these 3620 people from institutions NGOs TFSPs and academics have participated representing progress of 1206 with respect to the planned goal Additionally 1739 CFE members have participated
In the Perception Study and Capacity Assessment commissioned by the project a section was dedicated precisely to assessing to what extent training actions have helped to strengthen the capacities of the main stakeholders on issues promoted by the projectFor purposes of comparison groups of people under project intervention and not under project intervention were defined Specifically for TFSPs a set of questions of high technical difficulty was designed the questions were validated with experts
In this regard the average score or percentage of correct answers given by the TFSPs under project intervention was 82 meanwhile the TFSPs not under project intervention obtained a score of 65 which shows a notable difference of 17 between both groups

In June 2015 the third remeasurement of annual revenue in USD of the relevant CFEs determined through intensive monitoring was made the second remeasurement after the baseline adjustment in the 20122013 resulting in the following values
CFE Juanacatlán Jal 250508 USD
CFE San Pedro Jacuaro Mich 592126 USD
CFE San Rafael Ixtapaluca Pue 90146 USD
CFE Santo Domingo Coatlán Oax 677336 USD

CFE San Pablo Dgo 3583573 USD
CFE Ejido Yoquivo Chi 1891202 USD
CFE Ejido Álvaro Obregón Campeche 25157 USD
CFE Petcacab Q Roo 560783 USD
At the regional level by converting 2012 values which are those of the project baseline to current ones the average is as follows
Central Region 289861 USD which represents a 97 increase in annual revenue with respect to the baseline
Southern Region 380779 USD 38 lower annual revenue with respect to the baseline due to a decreased utilization volume authorized by the SEMARNAT for the ejido of Bajos de Balsamar
Northern Region 2551927 USD 38 more annual revenue with respect to the baseline
Southeast Region 273121 USD 65 less with respect to the baseline which is due to the persistence of the low sawmill operation in Álvaro Obregón and they are only dedicated to contract manufacturing of roundwood in small volumes
According to the foregoing there has been an average revenue increase of 18 with respect to the baseline However the South and Southeast regions had negative values Recorded negative values are largely due to the decrease in volumes authorized by the SEMARNAT It is important to mention that results during this period are are somewhat minimized when converted to US dollars because of the downward fluctuation of the peso as well as to reiterate that revenues are largely determined by volumes authorized by the SEMARNAT
To try to reverse the negative numbers in the Southern and Southeastern Regions the implementation of different strategies that will be based on the following areas is sought
Identifying specific market niches
Utilizing recycled resources
Regionlevel market studies for tropical wood products
On the other hand the MidTerm Review and the Project Board determined that monitoring only one CFE per state does not allow for the objective observation of project impact on competitiveness indicators of CFEs
In this regard in June 2015 the revenues of 35 CFEs in the project areas of focus was monitored Average revenues by region are shown below
Northern Region 7 CFEs 3944411 USD

East Central Region 7 CFEs 236914 USD
Southern Region 8 CFEs 434787 USD
Southeastern Region 6 CFEs 283371 USD
The average revenue for the 35 monitored CFEs is 1067663 USD per year
In 2016 the revenue of these same enterprises will be monitored again determine the amount of change with respect to the current period
In relation to investment in biodiversity the resources directly invested by the enterprises as well as the support resources received by the CONAFOR were considered and are related to actions aimed at conserving biodiversity

This represents 465 more than what was invested during the 20122013 period and almost eight times more than the level of investment recorded on the baseline 114547 USD

description.narrative: Community capacity is strengthened to achieve and maintain certification and to manage their forests in a sustainable and biodiversity friendly manner
1 Increase in number of forest communities receiving support to move towards certification

comment.narrative: Approx 225 communities in 4 project regions with potential to achieve certification
50 communities receiving assistance from project towards certification

In this period technical assistance was provided to 76 CFEs so that they would agree to supports to achieve certification
26 in the Northern Region 12 in Chihuahua and 14 in Durango
25 in the East Central Region 13 in Puebla 1 in Veracruz and 11 pieces of land in Hidalgo
10 in the Central Region 2 in Jalisco and 8 in Michoacán
5 in the Southern Region 5 CFEs in Oaxaca
10 in the Southeastern Region 4 in Campeche and 6 in Quintana Roo
In the areas with project involvement 89 pieces of land were aided by the PRONAFOR 2015 to attain certification in the amount of 516469 USD for a surface of 737935 ha Of these 33 were for CFEs of the Northern Region 11 PTA 3 NMX 19 FSC 24 of the Central Region 12 PTA 3 NMX 9 FSC 31 from the Central East Region 11 PTA 6 NMX 14 FSC and one from the Southern Region PTA
Additionally the CONAFOR provides support resources for certification processes with 45 CFEs of the projects areas of focus benefiting in 2015 with 368112 USD four PTAs of the Northern East Central and Southern Regions 33 for NMX certification of the Northern Central and East Central Regions eight pieces of land with support for FSC international certification the Northern Central and Eastern Regions
Furthermore with the second and third calls for PRONAFOR 2014 39 pieces of land were given support for certification under the three standards in the amount of 403881 USD 20 pieces of land in the Northern Region six pieces of land in the Central Region eight in the East Central Region three in the Southern Region and two in the Southeastern Region 37 pieces of land were given support for certification in the amount of 313312 USD 27 in the Northern Region and three pieces of land each in the East Central Region and the Southern Region and one more in the Southeastern Region
Cumulatively 400 CFEs have received technical assistance either directly from project personnel or from consultants hired to provide support to CFEs in our areas of focus
Results in terms of certificates obtained are described within the following indicator
On the other hand in the perception study the survey respondents were asked whether they believed that government support resources to promote forest certification had increased remained the same or decreased in recent years In response 67 said that they believe they have increased 26 believe they have remained the same and the rest of them believe that they have diminished
The foregoing tells us that increased priority and resources for forest certification is not just in numbers but also perceived by producers TFSPs and institutional personnel

description.narrative: 3 Number of Community Forestry Enterprises CFEs in biodiverse areas participating in the project and trained in BD management to apply safeguard measures in accordance with FSC Principles Criteria

40 CFEs trained in BD management

As a result of the specialized consultancy provided by the project 114 CFEs have concluded their studies to identify high conservation value areas
Additionally nearly 592 pieces of land are on record that incorporate biodiversity criteria into their FMPs based on the Best Biodiversity Conservation Practices Manual that the project produced in 2013 which has had an impact on an area of around 12 million ha Additionally with the CONAFORs support eight consultancies are in process of being hired to advise producers on incorporating biodiversity criteria into their FMPs on 720 pieces of land in the states of Chihuahua Durango Jalisco Michoacán Puebla Oaxaca Guerrero Campeche and Quintana Roo which amount to 11 million ha
The project designed a base structure to prepare Regional Biodiversity Studies RESs Currently there are 12 RESs in Chihuahua and Durango in their final stage of preparation They consider sitelevel foreststandlevel and landscapelevel biodiversity conservation practices on an area of 8 million ha
Likewise 131 Community Forest Enterprises CFEs were trained to prepare their Biological Monitoring and Habitat Quality Programs these tools allow them to obtain or maintain certification and provide information on the impact of productive activity on a piece of lands biodiversity Of these CFEs 71 have already prepared their monitoring programs 14 of which are implementing onsite activities Five courses that will train 46 more CFEs are planned for the second half of 2015

aOf the 37 CFEs that make up the baseline 29 have a valid forestry certificate17 of these 29 CFEs sell certified timber to Chain of Custodycertified purchasersThe average percentage of certified timber sold by these 17 CFEs to CoCcertified companies is 532 which shows an increase with respect to the 32 reported as a baseline in 2009
Furthermore eight other certified CFEs in addition to the baseline are recorded They sell 60 of their products on average to CoCcertified purchasers
In total there are 25 certified CFEs on record in the projects areas of focus that sell 5544 of their products on average to CoC purchasers Although the percentage of sales to CoCcertified purchasers is similar to that of the previous period the number of CFEs did increase from 14 to 25 which speaks to a greater volume of certified timber from legal sources reaching the end consumer
bOverall chain of custody CoC certification is one of the goals with the greatest progress in this period Until November 2014 the project had failed to obtain a single CoC certification However from December 2014 to June 2015 10 CoC certifications have been finalized This was because a maturing process was necessary for the CFEs starting with the certification of their pieces of land and everything which that entails in order to certify their industry
With these 10 CoC certifications and the 22 baseline ones there is cumulative progress of 76 32 CoC certifications Additionally there are another 12 enterprises in process of CoC certification in the East Central Region which the project supported by hiring four consultants who are providing specialized consultancy to integrate their Documented Control Systems
There are 193 companies nationwide with valid certificates among which include printing houses publishers cardboard and paper factories and forestry companies
cIn the Northern Region during this period another new partnership between forest ejidos for commercial purposes was incorporated as a result of the actions and specialized assistance of project personnel This Partnership is called Productos Silvícolas El Vergel ARIC which consists of six Ejidos one Community and one Small Property which belong to the municipality of Balleza
Additionally in the Northern Region there are two new partnerships of ejidos in process in Chihuahua that will be legally incorporated before a notary public in the third quarter of 2015 These are 1 Asociatividad Región de Basaseachi and 2 Silvicultores de la Región de Madera
In the Southeastern Region in collaboration with the CONABIO two groups of producers have received consultancy since 2014 in order to become part of a partnership model to process and market their products Finally the alliance called Carbón Vegetal y Biodiversidad de Calakmul Charcoal and Biodiversity in Calakmul was successfully established It is made up of two ejidos Álvaro Obregón y Nuevo Becal Campeche Alianza Selva Maya de Quintana Roo UE Mayan Jungle Alliance of Quintana Roo UE was also established and is made up of 5 ejidos Bacalar Felipe Carrillo Puerto NohBec Petcacab y Polinkín Xhazil and Annexes of the municipality of Felipe Carrillo Puerto Quintana Roo
For the past PIR the following three partnerships formed through intervention were reportedIn conclusion there have been four projectbased partnerships assembled from inception to their formal establishment by the project and two others formed through project collaboration with other partners In total six partnerships have been formed accounting for 30 of the progress toward the overall goal
It is noteworthy that although progress is behind schedule the project has promoted solid and functional partnership models that go beyond bringing ejidos together simply to market sawn timber

description.narrative: Monitoring learning adaptive feedback and evaluation systems are in place for quantitative and qualitative assessment of project impacts
1 Rate of deforestation and degradation in project impact study sites

comment.narrative:
The baseline expressed by type of use and average basal area ha is
1 Noncertified and utilization hiatus 2312 m2ha
2 Noncertified and in utilization 2289 m2has
3 Noncertified and protected natural area 2249 m2ha

5 Certified and in utilization hiatus 2023 m2ha
6 Certified and with utilization permit 2083 m2ha
7 Certified and in protected natural area 5478 m2ha
0 deforestation in certified sites lt10 of plots with reduced basal area in certified sites

In 2015 Remeasurement of Permanent Sites to Assess Changes in Deforestation Forest Degradation and Biodiversity in the State of Durango was produced To do so data from 155 permanent monitoring sites were used 108 site remeasured in 2013 and 47 in 2014
This task only took into account five management regimes in relation to the seven considered in the period period because of the temporary nature of the remeasurement of sites These were
1 Uncertified and utilization in suspension
2 Uncertified and with utilization permit
3 Certified and utilization in suspension
4 Certified and with utilization permit
5 Certified and on Natural Protected Areas
The foregoing enabled a comparative analysis related to monitoring 395 sites used in the previous study Regarding the number of trees N and the base area G which are variables that can be used to look for signs of forest degradation and deforestation the study resulted in the following rates of change in estimated mean values for these verifiers a positive value signifies an increase while a negative value represents a decrease
Uncertified and utilization in suspension rate of change for N 6512 rate of change for G 6746
Uncertified and with utilization permit rate of change for N632 rate of change for G 479
Certified and utilization in suspension rate of change for N 686 rate of change for G 479
Certified and with utilization permit rate of change for N 302 rate of change for G 1105
Certified and on Natural Protected Area rate of change for N 351 rate of change for G 1054
It is observed that management regimes 1 4 and 5 record positive rates of change which indicates increased cover and increased volumes from monitored sites In the regime of certified and utilization in suspension negative rates are observed which is interpreted as a sign of deforestation and forest degradation As important finding a significant increase in basal area in the regime if certificate and whit utilization permit was observed during this first period of observation this result is interesting because it can be considered an indicator showing that promotes responsible forest management increased forest cover
On the other hand in the East Central Region the Guide to establish Permanent Assessment Sites for Plant Diversity is under development It will be used to assess impacts from silvicultural treatments on pieces of land under management
Through this assessment the rates of deforestation and forest degradation in areas monitored can be defined based on basal area and woodland density indicators along with these indicators diversity will be measured in the shrub and herb layers thereby obtaining data for the species richness of a community changes in species composition and species richness between communities
In the PIR period the establishment of 160 of these sites in the region of the Sierra Norte de Puebla where the greatest number of certified pieces of land exists in the region was financed on four pieces of land with a valid utilization permit that are in operation and have a good management certificate based on these measurements the baseline of the already stated basal area and density per species was defined

description.narrative: 2 Rate of change in forest floral diversity proxy for overall BD in project impact study sites

comment.narrative:
The following baseline was established expressed by average richness of tree species and type of management
1 Noncertified and in utilization hiatus 8 species
2Noncertified and in utilization 7 species
3 Noncertified and protected natural area 6 species
4 Noncertified and without utilization permit 7 species
5 Certified and in utilization hiatus 7 species
6 Noncertified and in utilization 7 species
7 Certified and protected natural area 9 species
lt10 of plots with declining forest floral diversity in certified sites

Remeasurement of Permanent Sites to Assess Changes in Deforestation Forest Degradation and Biodiversity in Forests of the State of Durango also collected information on average tree species richness This work only considered five management regimes in relation to the seven considered in the previous period These regimes and the number of species for each one of them as well as the years of study are listed below 155 were considered during period 1 20082009 and 155 were considered during period 2 20132014
1 Uncertified and utilization in suspension 7 species two species decreased with respect to the previous period
2 Uncertified and with utilization permit 8 species remained the same with respect to the previous period
3 Certified and utilization in suspension 7 species remained the same with respect to the previous period
4 Certified and with utilization permit 8 species remained the same with respect to the previous period
5 Certified and on Natural Protected Areas 9 species remained the same with respect to the previous period
The results of the study still do not produce enough tested evidence to conclude that there is a decrease in negative impacts in certified forests in terms of deforestation forest degradation and loss of biodiversity in the area of study However the majority of the verifiers collected during the study display values or units of measurement that suggest that the certified forest regime exhibits better attributes for biodiversity conservation compared to the regime of uncertified management without utilization which was the only regime that exhibited decreases
Note The results presented above are from a comparison of 155 sites samples in the 20082009 period and 150 sites in the 20132014 period which therefore must be supplemented with remeasurement at other sites in order to more accurately assess spatial and temporal changes of the variables of Deforestation Forest Degradation and Biodiversity During the next two years the remaining sites will be remeasured which will allow for a better assessment of the baseline change dynamic defined in the previous study 395 Based on the foregoing in relation to the baseline they might not match

Of the nine CFEs monitored for competitiveness indicators a baseline for women working for these enterprises was also prepared
In this regard in 2012 of the 308 workers in these nine CFEs three were women that is only 1 That year only three of the nine enterprises had women in their workforce The average number of women per CFE was 06 in 2012
In June 2015 there are 18 women working within the operations of the nine CFEs representing 4 of total workers Seven of the nine CFEs now have at least one women in their workforces In 2015 the average number of women in these nine CFEs is two
To have a more objective overview of the level of participation of women in CFE operations gender information was collected in June 2015 from a sample of 36 CFEs receiving project support This will allow us to have a more meaningful baseline that will serve to compare it to the results obtained in 2016
Below are the numbers by region taken from monitoring 36 CFEs
Northern Region 137 women working in seven CFEs 19 women per EFC on average

Central Region Six women working in seven CFEs less than one woman per EFC on average
Southern Region 22 women working in eight CFEs about three women per EFC on average
Southeastern Region 19 women working in six CFEs three women per EFC on average
There are 189 women recorded as working in the 36 CFEs of all the regions nationwide This means five women on average per each CFE 24 of the 36 CFEs have at least one woman working in their workforces 66
The percentage of women working in relation to the total number of workers of these 36 CFEs is 9
Furthermore as mentioned in the section on training 491 women attended coursesworkshops organized by the project in this period which means that they represent 16 of attendees Of the women who were trained 25 developed their certification capacities 17 were trained in biodiversity 16 in competitiveness and markets 11 in biological monitoring 11 in Forest Management and 1 in HCV
With respect to where the trained women come from 31 are from CFEs 24 are Technical Forestry Service Providers 19 are from academia 12 are from the CONAFOR 7 are from NGOs 4 are from the SEMARNAT 2 are from State Governments 1 are from the PROFEPA 04 are from the CONANP and 04 are from the CONABIO
Additionally as reported in the previous report the project has provided special consultancy and undertaken actions to include a gender perspective in regulatory and planning instruments that have undergone updatingdrafting processes
Finally in the perception study conducted by the project some test items to monitor the perception of womens participation in forestry activity were included
Regarding the question During the last five years of womens participation in forestry activities on forest lands and in the forestry enterprise sawmill has it decreased remained the same or increased Of those surveyed 52 believed that it had remained the same 41 believed that it has increased and 7 believed that it has decreased
Regarding the question During the next five years of womens participation in forestry activities on forest lands and in the forestry enterprise sawmill will it decrease remain the same or increase Of those surveyed 69 believe that it will remain the same 26 believe that it will increase and 5 believe that it will decrease

description.narrative: Technical assistance for community forest certification is institutionalized within national programs

The capacity building program of the Project is successful and has exceeded the goals set on the matter The technical capacities of CONAFOR personnel forestry service providers and institutions on the environment certification issues biodiversity and forest management forest monitoring and HCVs were strengthened and the issue of competitiveness and markets was also included which is the largest area of opportunity identified in the MidTerm Review
During this period 1782 people from the institutions were trained in the aforementioned issues broken down as follows 294 people of the CONAFOR 818 forestry service providers and 670 people from other institutions relating to the environment
Of the total people trained from institutions 16 are CONAFOR personnel 5 are of the SEMARNAT 15 of the CONABIO 1 of the PROFEPA 05 of the CONANP 46 are technical forestry service providers 6 are from state governments 14 are academics and 9 are from NGOs
During the lifespan of the project 3620 people from institutions have been trained in the subjects in question of which 1790 53 were TFSPs and 1830 47 belong to federal agencies and NGOs With this the goal for trained institutional personnel has been surpassed
With regard to training TFSP offices there 138 offices on record that received this support which signifies progress of more than 1000 in relation to the planned goal The breakdown of trained offices by region is described below
Northern Region 50 offices
Central Region 14 offices
East Central Region 21 offices
Southern Region 22 offices
Southeastern Region 31 offices
Cumulatively in the projects lifespan so far 162 TFSP offices unduplicated are on record as trained in the topics promoted by the project This TSFP training strategy has had excellent results as the profession has become an arm of the project that supports the dissemination and implementation of good biodiversity conservation practices and other matters

description.narrative: 2 Increased priority given to biodiversity goals in national production forest policies and programs

comment.narrative:
Govt target to expand certification by 1 million ha nationwide
CONAFOR evaluations of proposals for funding do not prioritize BD values and aims
260000yr invested specifically in BD through CONAFOR production forestry programs

National strategy for certification expansion prioritizing BDrich forests
BD criteria integrated in CONAFOR evaluation of external proposals
50 increase in BDspecific investment by CONAFOR production forestry programs

a As reported in the previous period forest certification and biodiversity conservation are priorities established in the National Forestry Program One indicator of the importance of forest certification to the Mexican government is the national goal set in the PRONAFOR to triple certified area by 2018 which is leading to a substantial increase in institutional investment intended to support forest certification
The Mexican Standard NMXAA143SCFI2008 for certification of sustainable forest management has been strengthened with project inputs by making the criteria related to biodiversity conservation mandatory as well as identifying high conservation value attributes connectivity of habitats and conservation of vertical and horizontal structures essential for biodiversity conservation
The project also has participated in incorporating and strengthening the Mexican Forest Certification Council A consultancy was hired to develop the Internal Rules of Operation and support said Councils formalization process before a notary public
Through a consultant hired by the project the Manual establishing the guidelines for Preventive Technical Audits was amended strategic changes were made for its concurrence with the Mexican Standard on certification of sustainable forest management along with changes to the National Forestry Certification SystemRecently the process to update the FSC International Certification Standard began The project is participating in the review of 3 of its criteria which will promote the incorporation of biodiversity conservation and a gender approach
Also in response to one of the main recommendations of the MidTerm Review on promoting the drafting of a chain of custody standard the project has participated in drafting and reviewing the assessment procedure for chain of custody forestry processes developed by the Asociación de Normalización y certificación AC ANCE
bThe project contributed to amendments to the PRONAFOR Rules of Operation for 2013 2014 and 2015 in collaboration with the Offices of Forest Development Community Forest Development and Supply Chain Integration thereby providing technical inputs to the National Sustainable Forest Management Strategy for Increasing Production and Productivity
Moreover the Project financed the implementation of eight regional courses on regulation management and forest health coordinated by the Secretariat of Environment and Natural Resources which were attended by 1700 people from the SEMARNAT PROFEPA CONAFOR CONANP TFSPs academics forest producers and othersIt is worth mentioning that through these courses it was possible to hasten acceptance of biodiversity conservation among public servants and other stakeholders mentioned above
cWhile the support concept of Carrying out Specialized Technical Studies to Establish Conservation Areas Rich in Biodiversity is not present in the 2015 Rules of Operation support resources to prepare studies for biodiversity conservation an HCVA Study and Regional Biodiversity Studies are granted through the following supports Certification and Regional Studies to Support Sustainable Forest Management
During this cycle the CONAFOR invested 141799 USD in the concept of international certification meant for preparing HCV studies and 454227 to develop 13 Regional Biodiversity Studies through the concept of Regional Studies to Support Sustainable Forest Management which cumulatively amounts to 596026 for the period which signifies more than 229 relative to the average annual investment recorded on the baseline 260000 USD
Cumulatively in the projects lifespan so far the CONAFOR has directly invested 3981617 USD in support resources for biodiversity conservation in production forests

description.narrative: 3 Increase in federal and state demand for certified wood products from CFEs resulting in sales contracts

comment.narrative:
Federal policy requiring sourcing of certified material
1 statelevel policy
0 contracts executed as a result of clarified sourcing information and new policies

Federal policy prioritizing Mexican CFE certified material
5 new state policies
15 new contracts executed

One of the projects main areas of opportunity is the development of national government demand for certified timber It is a complex issue that requires the involvement of several federal agencies SHCP SEMARNAT SEP etc However the project has made progress in generating information and projects that can have an impact on consolidating the demand for certified forest products by public institutions
Study of the sawn timber market
In December 2014 the Study of the Sawn Timber Market in Mexico was finalized It includes an analysis of market conditions and sawn timber from tropical species in Mexico and the demand for certified timber products by the federal government state governments and the private sector
National Wood Energy Program
As part of the projects strategies to develop and diversify the demand for products derived from sustainable forest management the implementation of projects to generate electricity from forest biomass has been identified as a viable option In this regard the project financed the implementation of the National Wood Energy Program PRONADEN from which a first draft was already generated which underwent validation before a group of experts and the comments received are in process of being addressedApart from containing the strategies to be followed by the project and the CONAFOR on power generation through forest biomass
Green Procurement Decree
Through the Forest Development Office and in collaboration with the project the CONAFOR is reviewing the Decree whereby Various Measures for Procurement Paper Usage and Certification of Sustainable Forest Management by the Federal Government better known as the Green Procurement Decree and the Law on Procurement Leasing and Services for the Public Sector
Based on an analysis of these regulations it is necessary to adjust them therefore a proposal for additions and reforms must be presented that will define what the mechanism will be to ensure traceability of national certified products from harvesting areas to consumers
This is intended to encourage and promote purchases of certified products that are required by public entities and includes the responsibilities and obligations of those who are hired for construction services within the Public Administration in order to ensure that the wood used also comes from certified sourcesThe proposal will be presented to SEMARNAT to form a working group to examine what adjustments are requiredThe preliminary proposal is set to be ready by the end of 2015
Likewise the project will make any necessary adjustments to its planning by seeking to free up resources to hire a specialized consultant who may follow up on this issue from the review of the Decree and Law on Procurement to the drafting of a specific proposal to amend the mentioned legislation and make proposals for procurement protocols at the state level
Michoacán Procurement Agreement
The Michoacán Government Procurement Agreement has failed to materialize because the state has had three different governors who all have installed their own working teams upon taking power which has led to constant changes in the key positions involved in the signing of the Agreement
Regarding the goal of procurement contractsagreements entered into with public institutions the former partner of the Project the Rainforest Alliance RA was working with the CFE el Balcón Guerrero to make sales of certified products However these developments were not reported because the evidence of such purchases and sales was not availableIn November 2014 as part of the proof of the resources entrusted to them the RA presented 16 invoices for 12 procurement contracts that were signed by agencies of the State Government of Guerrero and by a municipal governmentIn the 2013 PIR three more formalized agreements had been reported which reaches the goal of 15 certified timber procurement agreementscontracts with public institutions

comment.narrative: Grupo MABE es, con una cuota de producción de cerca de 25%, uno de los productores más grandes de refrigeración en América Latina. La compañía tiene cuatro líneas de producción de espumaLa linea de producción 3 utiliza tanto HCFCs como HFC245fa en la producción de los cuerpos de refrigeradores y puertas. El consumo de HCFC de la empresa se calcula en 1,424.7 toneladas de SAO (julio 2009). Se sustituirá el uso de HCFCs por ciclopentano con el apoyo del proeycto. Mabe hará la reconversión del resto de sus líneas por su cuenta.

INECC's vision is to become a leader agency in applied environmental research, that develops and promotes scientific cooperation projects that contribute effectively to resolve the major environmental problems of Maxico, and support the conservation and restoration of the environment in the whole country.

comment.narrative: Cero escenarios nacionales actualizados y que profundizan en la modelación de reducción de escala Los 32 Planes estatales de acción climática en desarrollo o concluidos contemplan el uso de modelos peor no están homogeneizados; hay algunos planes regionales y municipales; las universidades, tecnológicos (instituciones académicas) han hecho estudios de forma aislada. Cero registros que integran el análisis de detección de cambios en el clima observado para analizar sus proyecciones y evaluar la vulnerabilidad y medidas de adaptación actual y futura. Cero escenarios de vulnerabilidad desarrollados con información socioeconómica y ambiental a nivel regional, estatal y local. Existe el Marco de Políticas de Adaptación, la estrategia Nacional de Adaptación, la Ley General de Cambio Climático. Se ha impulsado un proceso de fortalecimiento de capacidades en la Península de Yucatán para apoyar el desarrollo de una estrategia Regional de Adaptación. Se han impulsado los programas especiales de cambio climático Tres mecanismos y/o plataformas en marcha para el intercambio de información, conocimiento y experiencias sobre cambio climático. Cero metodologías de seguimiento y rastreo de financiamiento climático y de seguimiento y evaluación del ingreso y destino final de los recursos climáticos Cero Unidades Administrativas que cuentan con el software instalado y operando con funcionalidad

Implementación de consultorías relacionadas a aplicación de escenarios: 1) Análisis espacial de escenarios de cambio climático 2) Diseño de un geoportal para visualizar el Atlas Nacional de Vulnerabilidad al cambio climático 3) Elaboración de dos cursos virtuales sobre escenarios de cambio climático 4) Impactos del cambio climático y costos, elaboración de nuevos escenarios
Implementación de convenio para generar nuevos escenarios: 1) Convenio para nuevos escenarios de reducción de escala dinámica y estadística, con IMTA
Implementación de consultorías relacionadas a detección de cambios: 1) Análisis de eventos extremos en México 2) Tendencias climáticas y de cambio climático en 11 ciudades del país 3) Impactos en agricultura por cambio climático 4) Desiertos y cambio climático
Implementación de convenios con instituciones para aplicación de modelos: 1) Convenio para nuevos escenarios de reducción de escala dinámica y estadística, con IMTA 2) Convenio para identificar vulnerabilidades y sus variables, con COLEF 3) Convenio para evaluar costas y cambio climático, con UABC 4) Convenio para elaborar índice de vulnerabilidad institucional, con TM
Además, en adelante: Personas que tomen uno de los dos cursos virtuales sobre escenarios de cambio climático en los estados
Implementación de consultorías con nuevos escenarios de vulnerabilidad: 1) V de Suelos 2) V de zonas Bioclimáticas, 3) V de Islas 4) V de recursos Hídricos 5) V de Agricultura 6) V de Desiertos 7) V Económica 8) V de Costas 9) V de Ciudades 10) V de Instituciones Implementación de talleres para fortalecimiento de capacidades y contratación de facilitación del proceso Conformación del geoportal con el Atlas Nacional de Vulnerabilidad al Cambio Climático Cursos virtuales sobre escenarios de cambio climático Consultoría sobre financiamiento climático en curso Unidad administrativa del proyecto con software instalado

Utilizando el modelo climático de reescalamiento (downscaling), el SDSM (Statistical Downscaling Model) se realizaron escenarios climáticos a corto, mediano y largo plazo, con dos rutas de concentración representativa de las siguientes ciudades: Aguascalientes, Mexicali BCN., Tijuana BC.N, Zona Metropolitana de la Ciudad de México, Veracruz, Puebla, Chihuahua, Guadalajara, León, Tuxtla Gutiérrez, Monterrey, Querétaro, Tlaxcala y Toluca. 2 herramientas para favorecer la interlocución y conformación de redes: DIRECTORIO de académicos y funcionarios de gobierno y sociedad civil organizada que generen metodologías e investigación sobre vulnerabilidad e impactos al cambio climático y DIRECTORIO de actores académicos y funcionarios de gobierno y sociedad civil organizada y sector privado, que implementen acciones de adaptación 1 Taller para favorecer la Red nacional de modelación del clima y Creación de la red nacional de modelación de vulnerabilidad, impactos y adaptación al cambio climático, 21 funcionarios del INECC 1 Taller de Análisis de Tendencias del Clima y con cambio climático para las ciudades más pobladas del país impartido a 17 funcionarios/as del INECC, SEMARNAT y la Universidad Veracruzana, donde se proporcionaron elementos mínimos necesarios para producir escenarios climáticos locales con el SDSM, y presentar resultados de escenarios climáticos en algunas ciudades de México con aplicación de SDSM. 1 Curso virtual sobre conceptos generales de cambio 1 Curso virtual sobre escenarios de cambio climático 1 Geoportal con el Atlas Nacional de Vulnerabilidad al Cambio Climático montado Adicionalmente se ha generado: Cartografía, Bases de datos de estaciones meteorológicas Se entregaron bases de datos diarios de las estaciones por región (T y P), con control de calidad y homogeneidad de los mismos Se fortaleció la capacidad de análisis técnico de los resultados de la Plataforma a través de la actualización de equipo para la Coordinación de la DGACC 1 Seminar

description.narrative: El proyecto tiene como objetivo transformar la gestión y cobertura de las áreas protegidas terrestres y costeras en México para atenuar los impactos directos e indirectos del cambio climático en la biodiversidad de interés mundial.
capital of a political entity
second-order administrative division
La resiliencia al CC se integra al sistema de ANP de México Sostenibilidad financiera para aumentar la resiliencia del sistema de ANP mexicana

comment.narrative: El sistema de áreas naturales protegidas de México se configuró espacialmente y se logró aumentar la resiliencia a los impactos adversos del cambio climático sobre la diversidad biológica

Bajo nivel de integración de la resiliencia al cambio climático dentro del sistema de áreas naturales protegidas de México a través de instrumentos de planificación, gestión y financieros:
- La Estrategia de Cambio Climático desde las Áreas Naturales Protegidas (ECCAP) incluye resiliencia al cambio climático y se alinea a los documentos legales rectores de la política de atención al cambio climático (Ley General de Cambio Climático; Estrategia Nacional de Cambio Climático; Programa Especial de Cambio Climático 2014 – 2018; Programa Nacional de Desarrollo) - 9 POA que incluyen actividades de atención al cambio climático especificados en el componente específico del PM. - Al menos 1 POA que incluya actividades de atención al cambio climático especificadas en su Programa de Adaptación al Cambio Climático (PACC) - Publicación de al menos un PACC de las áreas protegidas piloto. - Proceso de elaboración de los PACC para que las 17 ANP piloto del proyecto tengan medidas específicas de adaptación identificadas y con estrategias de aplicación. - Identificar las principales actividades elaboradas por las ANP piloto del Proyecto relacionadas a la atención al cambio climático e incremento de la resiliencia. - Coordinación multisectorial sobre los esfuerzos e inversiones en áreas naturales protegidas a nivel subnacional a través del desarrollo del por medio de la colaboración multisectorial con socios principales.

Bajo nivel de integración de la resiliencia al cambio climático dentro del sistema de áreas naturales protegidas de México a través de instrumentos de planificación, gestión y financieros:
- La Estrategia de Cambio Climático desde las Áreas Naturales Protegidas (ECCAP) incluye resiliencia al cambio climático y se alinea a los documentos legales rectores de la política de atención al cambio climático (Ley General de Cambio Climático art. 7 sección III; Estrategia Nacional de Cambio Climático; Programa Especial de Cambio Climático 2014 – 2018; Programa Nacional de Desarrollo) - 9 POA que incluyen actividades de atención al cambio climático especificados en el componente específico del PM. - 1 POA que incluye actividades de atención al cambio climático especificadas en su PACC. - PACC final publicado para un área natural protegida piloto del Proyecto (Reserva de la Biósfera Mapimí) - Borrador final en revisión de un PACC de un área natural protegida piloto del Proyecto (Área de Protección de Flora y Fauna Islas del Golfo de California – Sonora). - Proceso de elaboración de los PACC para que las 17 ANP piloto del proyecto tengan medidas específicas de adaptación identificadas y con estrategias de aplicación. - Por medio de los POA, se identificaron las actividades de atención al cambio climático en 17 ANP. En 10 de ellas, estas actividades se encuentran privilegiadas en los componentes específicos del PM. En una (RB Mapimí), se encuentran especificadas en el PACC. - Coordinación multisectorial sobre los esfuerzos e inversiones en áreas naturales protegidas a nivel subnacional por medio de la firma de acuerdos de colaboración con socios potenciales y el arranque del trabajo colaborativo con otros socios estratégicos. A través del proyecto, se firma un acuerdo de colaboración entre CONANP, CONABIO y CONAFOR para la atención al cambio climático y resiliencia. Es el primero en su tipo en el país y busca consolidarse a través de una plataforma de información de cambio cli

1. Nivel MEDIO de integración de la resiliencia a cambio climático dentro de áreas naturales protegidas de México a través de instrumentos de plantificación, gestión y financieros: Marco institucional del sistema de áreas naturales protegidas mexicanas fortalecido con criterios de cambio climático y resiliencia que permitan salvaguardar la biodiversidad de manera efectiva. Instrumentos de planificación, gestión y operación institucionalizados que incluyen un componente de resiliencia al cambio climático. Al menos 4 instrumentos de planificación, gestión y operación institucionalizados que incluyen un componente de resiliencia al cambio climático. 2. Ampliar el sistema de áreas naturales protegidas en sitios con conectividad estratégica con criterios de resiliencia al cambio climático. Número de hectáreas nuevas incorporadas al sistema de áreas naturales protegidas con al menos un esquema de financiamiento de acciones de conservación. 10,000 hectáreas nuevas incorporadas al sistema de áreas naturales protegidas con al menos un esquema de financiamiento de acciones de conservación. Promover una gestión efectiva de las áreas naturales protegidas para reducir las amenazas climáticas a la biodiversidad. Puntaje de la herramienta Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT) sobre la gestión efectiva de las áreas naturales protegidas. Al menos 79% de puntaje de la herramienta de Calificación de la herramienta Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT) sobre la gestión efectiva de las áreas naturales protegidas al cierre del Proyecto.

description.narrative: The Mexican Protected Area system is spatially configured and managed to increase resilience to the adverse impacts of climate change on biological diversity
The Mexican Protected Area system is spatially configured and managed to increase resilience to the adverse impacts of climate change on biological diversity

comment.narrative:
1 CONANP has a Climate Change Strategy but resilience to CC is not reflected in planning and management instruments
2 CONANP budget does not address resilience activities No multisectorial coordination platform exists regarding efforts and investments on PA at a subnational level

1 CONANP planning and management instruments mainstream CC resilience
2 Internal budgetary restructuring to allocate 10 of CONANP budget to resilience activities Multisectorial platform to attain budgetary coordination

1
CONANPs legal framework includes CC and resilience 100
Mainstreaming of resilience instruments within the PA system is being done in 96 of the CONANP areas
During Year 1 the inclusion of CC resilience concepts and its attendance have been successfully included in the legal framework of the Mexican PA system
CONANP Strategy for 2040
PNANP 2013 2018
ECCAP updated and aligned with public and institutional policy PNANP and legal national framework related to CC
The instrumentation of CC attendance is being carried in 96 of the total federal PA in Mexico covering nearly 30 of national terrestrial and marine biodiversity
Collaboration agreements with other institutions are being arranged From Year 2 this represents an opportunity window to promote CC resilience concepts in their planning and management instruments to decrease biodiversity vulnerability towards it
Special focus on 17 PA by the project is currently undergoing with field representatives that promote the CC resilience instruments in the planning instruments and management activities It is through the Annual Operative Programs of each PA that specific activities are being executed to detect and attend potential impacts of CC on biodiversity
2 Collaboration agreements with other institutions represent the first step towards multisectorial coordination From Year 2 coordination is being promoted to achieve the development of the multisectorial platform

description.narrative: Expansion of PA system to protect important refugia through connectivity and increased resiliency
Area of functional connectivity between critical habitat blocks surrounding and within PAs maintained or increased to enhance ecosystem resilience through ecoregionbased incentive schemes

comment.narrative:
0 ha
General incentives exist for BD conservation

30000 ha that enhance connectivity and ecoregion incentives schemes as a partial result from management actions from Outcome 3
12 ecoregion based incentive schemesportfolios that enhance resilience

0 ha The scientific research to identify the potential areas of functional connectivity between critical habitat blocks have begun
Priority conservations sites have been identified by means of analysis of ecoregional system of monarch butterfly an indicator species Its migratory path was registered to identify priority habitat blocks It was found that the species transits through 12 different vegetation types in the country over one third of the types present in Mexico A former study identified that over 35540 km2 correspond to the remaining natural vegetation found in protected zones along the migration route of monarch butterfly In a latter study critical habitat blocks to be strengthened will be identified by means of an incentive scheme of CONANPs Program of Conservation and Sustainable Development PROCODES by its acronym in Spanish
There is a previous study on land vertebrates connectivity in a climate change context generated through a collaboration between CONANP and WWF Carlos Slim foundation which shall also be used as input for obtaining regional connectivity maps during year 2 aligned to institutional and sector objectives
Incentive schemesportfolios that enhance resilience in 8 of the PA of the Project
Efforts have been made in the project at PA San Pedro Mártir so that projects financed by an incentive scheme of Temporary Employment Program PET and Conservation Program for Sustainable Development PROCODES of CONANP have components which allow for the mitigation and adaptation to Climate Change During Year 1 an approach has been made to the rest of PA to set this goal and the intention is that at least one PROCODES project for each of the PA be successful in this regard during Year 2

description.narrative: Expansion of areas of conservation in priority ecoregions and refugia facilitated by GIS database measured by the increase in area under conservation to promote connectivity and protect important refugia

comment.narrative: 0 ha total ANP 25384818 ha

25984818 ha At least 600000 ha of new areas included in new or existing conservation areas nationwide
Coastalmarine 369139 ha
Terrestrial 230861 ha
By Year 2 a strategy will define distribution between the 12 ecoregions linked to the information system and GIS from Outcome 1

0 ha of new areas have been included in the National Protected Areas System never the less 37 thousand ha have been identified by social counterparts for conservation in the surrounding areas of PA Along with these more than 1 million ha are in process of being declared as a part of the NPAS in the Sierras La Giganta and Guadalupe in the state of Baja California Sur
During Year 1 of the Project there have been identified and prioritized 2 sites for expansion and connectivity of the PA that are part of the Project The process of validation of those areas as expansion sites strengthening connectivity will be carried out during years 2 3 and 4 to reach over 37 thousand ha distributed as follows
1 Voluntary conservation sites in Chihuahua strengthening PA Janos with 16 thousand ha
2 Support for redefining the estate at Cañón del Sumidero and the potential update to the category of PA Villa Allende both in the state of Chiapas with a potential of 21 thousand ha
Synergy was achieved towards strengthening connectivity while intending conservation activities to be planned and operated regionally along with PA state system comprising La Pera Laguna Bélgica and Cerro Meyapak The participation of these PA as a whole alongside the Project is of the utmost importance since they hold Subsecretariats of Environment Forest Development and Climate Change within their structure
The project has strengthened the preliminary supporting study and accompanied overall process including consultation and institutional meetings in order to declare Sierras as PA by means of the inclusion of the conceptual framework of Climate Change and Resilience This will promote connectivity among PA in the region El Vizcaíno Bahías de Loreto Balandra and Sierra La Laguna increasing conservation surface in at least 1 million ha
During yearend 1 it is being carried out a study on the current situation and extension of marine reserves in Región de Grandes Islas y Norte del Golfo de California This will allow for the identification of refugia sites of conservation and of potential connectivity channels The results shall be ready at the end of the second quarter of Year 2

description.narrative: Mexican PA system readiness framework effectively safeguards BD
Institutional framework strengthened to increase PA resilience from CC impacts and risks

comment.narrative: Communication strategy provides limited promotion of conservation areas as instruments of resilience

Communication Strategy by Year 2 promotes the importance of conservation areas as instruments to a increase resilience of communities and ecosystems and b maintain integrity across the landscapeseascape

Communication strategy during Year 1 has focused on spreading the concept of Resilience of PA facing CC within the institution
During the first stage an awareness campaign took place around those publications of institutional planning which show the connection with the national program framework regarding Climate Change They are distributed electronically via the Climate Change site of CONANP as well as in print
1 Publication of ECCAP in an executive summary format with a print run of 5000 copies in Spanish and 5000 in English
2 Publication of the 2040 Strategy in the form of 5000 copies of the full text 5000 executive summaries and 5000 posters to be distributed among all personnel of PA
3 400 copies of DRV Tool are published for its distribution and use within PA
Besides the physical and digital distribution of the documentation the project is spreading the official information through the participation in the meetings of Advisor Councils of the PAs In order to make aware of the changes in the legal framework of the institution to the personnel of CONANP the project has made agreements with the Internal Communication department to spread the information through the CONANPs structure
Parallel to these actions a Project Fair was organized as the closing event of the First Series of Conferences on Climate Change see further details in Outcome 3 It was sought to make known those projects implemented within PA about mitigation and adaptation to Climate Change within the country The head of CONANP identified the potential of this initiative and as a result gave instructions to the Directorate of Strategies for Climate Change to support the more advanced project as a reference point for other PA since its characteristics are an example of the application of strategies for the adaptation to climate change A Second Project Fair is planned for Year 2 with a different approach to encourage PA to present small projects that improve system resilience On Years 3 to 5 the Project looks forward to developing the permanence of resilient projects that can be applied in PA in the first place
The objectives of this strategy are also designed to allocate areas of coincidence between national policies regarding climate change and the commitments of UNDP as shown in CPD 20142018 in order to effectively communicate the results observed in those communities and ecosystems where the project is applied
In Year 2 the communication strategy will attempt to widen its coverage to include differentiated audiences according to the nature of the message and to the media used In the beginning it promotes the identification of the most efficient approach to identify the importance of preservation of PA facing the 3 outcomes of the project Thus during this period in the report a second series of audiovisual materials Faros de Esperanza has begun its production intending to promote PA as a natural solution to CC
The first series was developed before the beginning of the Project but it had a positive impact as a diffusion strategy to the specialized and general public As a result of this the second series was conceived as a need to be included in the communication strategy
Besides along with the development of abilities in field officers there are plans to produce support materials to strengthen the spread of the concept Resilience with the cooperation of experts from Stockholm Resilience Centre and UNDP These collaborations are the result of the development of a common concept of Resilience in PA developed during the international seminar carried on in Morelos Mexico during Year 1 This event was designed to achieve a common scientific knowledge on the concept with a complete description and measurable indicators to interchange experiences and to create synergies with international institutions that could lead to the development of educational materials that could impact the general and the specialized public

description.narrative: Planning Management and Information System for decision making to mainstream CC into integrated landuse planning that increases biodiversity resilience

comment.narrative:
No PA has CC resilience mainstreamed in its planning and management instruments
No National Climate Information Portal for Protected Areas exists
0 PAs with access to Portal

National Climate Information Portal for Protected Areas established with geospatial data including an Early Alert System and linked to the already existing monitoring efforts as SNIB INFyS and SIMEC and other relevant initiatives
100 PAs with access to Portal and staff trained to use it to make effective resiliencebased management decisions

The National Climate Information Portal for Protected Areas is in an early stage of development 20 achieved
Training in existing monitoring efforts as an action of adaptation to climate change was carried on in 13 PA of the Project
Incorporation of CONABIO as a responsible partner of the project as derived from the substantive revision of ProDoc will promote its development in year 2
This collaboration will give the Project the chance to get information of the MADMEX platform Monitoring Reporting Verification Activity Data in Mexico for its acronym in Spanish that was developed for the REDD Program The close work with CONABIO and CONAFOR as a second partner will allow us to get information on degradation because it intends to estimate annual changes in the extension of forest ecosystems Obtaining this kind of data will allow decision maker of the PA to identify those spots where changes in land use and potential points of landscape degradation are perceived Also this will enhance the capacity to make scientific based decisions Outcome 3
Sistema de Alta Resolución de Monitoreo de Diversidad y Degradación SARMOD
The Project participates in the initiative of the Sistema de Alta Resolución de Monitoreo de Diversidad y Degradación SARMOD on ecosystems with a participation of 76 of the project PA Ecosystem monitoring is complementary to the institutional efforts taking place nowadays in relation to monitoring along with other projects conforming the climate change monitoring system of CONANP
This tool is intended to analyze Ecosystem Integrity IE by means of an approximation by modeling of the complexity of the structure and function of ecosystems In collaboration with Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation the Mexican Fund for the Conservation of Nature and the Fund for Protected Areas 23 PA have already attended and in Year 2 they will reach 33 PA
Effective resiliencebased management decisions
One work of regional impact of climate change in the PA Mariposa Monarca was carried on with the purpose of attaining greater scientific information needed in decision making during the implementation activities and in the mainstreaming of the concept of Climate Change and Resilience
Another two work on the same topic is being promoted in the Islas del Golfo California PA and in Constitución de 1857 PA They will be finished and published during Year 2
On year 2 consultancy related to the characterization of sites and environmental services will take place in the remaining 14 PA related to their expected response to climate change
This kind of work helps to identify actions and responses to possible impacts of Climate Change in order to strength the PA Management Programs and the Intersectorial Coordination Instruments
By means of integrating the concepts of Resilience and Climate Change to the Annual Operative Programs POA of the Protected Areas in the projects priority conservation activities have been mainstreamed with an adaptive approach based on ecosystems

Capacity Development of CONANPs staff and of field officers
On Year 1 capabilities have been enhanced both within and outside the project personnel
One of the challenges is guaranteeing that the initiatives developed have permanence beyond that of the estimated life span of the Project This is proof of the institutional strengthening that is sought in Outcome 1
Consequently an elearning module on Climate Change has been developed within mandatory training 40hour courses for inhouse staff of CONANP On Year 2 its implementation on the on line learning platform of the institution shall be put into effect
It was sought that Project operative field personnel had the proper safety capabilities to carry out their activities Consequently the project supported 13 out of its 17 field officers at taking up the Safety and first aid course taught by the Mexican Navy Now the staff is in proper conditions to perform their duties in a safe manner This knowledge was reinforced by setting up a First Aid kit to offer the necessary tools which were appropriate to the skills developed during the course During year 2 staff from the Project Coordinating Unit and the totality of field officers shall take up this course so they can all have safetyrelated topics internalized
Moreover regarding safety topics all field officers and the Project Coordinating Unit received safety training at the UN taught by UNDP
The Project has supported field officers training according to PAspecific needs so they can carry out the activities needed to achieve projects goals Every officer has received training on Year 1 and it is planned during year 2 to replicate that training on the rest of the operational staff in their PA The training taking place is as follows
a Geographic Information System using Quantum GIS freeware
b Prevention and fighting of forest fires
c Ecosystem services monitoring and assessment techniques
d Trainers development for the assessment of PA management effectiveness
e Gender mainstreaming guidelines in mitigation and adaptation to Climate Change efforts taught by IUCN
f Capacity Works taught by the German Cooperation for Development GIZ by its name in German
g Conflict management and dialogue building taught by UNDP
Each of these training courses are planned to be replicated or applied in the PA In some cases the abilities of the officer have allowed for the development of capacities in the inhouse staff of the PA as well as in members of the civil society Applying the acquired knowledge in conflict management can be underscored as well as training offered to tourist service providers regarding Climate Change Sustainable Development and Resilience
During the report period it has been spread specialized information regarding different topics associated to climate change among all personnel at the institution both at the central headquarters in Mexico City and in all other parts of the country In this regard the Conference Series on Climate Change has received full support calling for a second edition which was broadcasted remotely as well as setting personnel on the site to assist those events Eight master conferences took place some of them being broadcasted from the different Regional Directorates where the Project is present The quality and spread of the information has been estimated as able to have an impact on 100 computers remotely connected to the broadcast with an approximate total of 1700 participants allowing for the creation of Climate Change knowledge networks at different levels
The information transmitted has been of global policies Paris 2015 agreement Carbon Storage Ecosystem Services Valuation Risk derived from Climate Change Governance Climate Change and Marine Ecosystems Environmental Education on Climate Change Carbon Voluntary Markets These conferences have been institutionalized and are part of the training of the CONANPs personnel

Cuatro documentos de investigación para posterior redacción del Informe sobre Desarrollo Humano en México: movilidad social. Tres documentos de investigación con potencial uso para revisión de políticas públicas y estrategias temáticas en materia de pobreza.
Sobre la base de estos documentos, se han establecido los siguientes indicadores:

comment.narrative: No existen aún documentos de investigación elaborado por la OIDH para posterior redacción del Informe sobre Desarrollo Humano en México: movilidad social.
Finalización del Informe sobre Desarrollo Humano en México 2016: desigualdad y movilidad.

Se logró la meta de construir el quinto Informe sobre Desarrollo Humano México 2016. Desigualdad y movilidad; la cual, es la contribución más reciente del Programa de las Naciones Unidas para el Desarrollo (PNUD) al debate público en favor del bienestar de las personas. La publicación busca dirigir la atención del gobierno y de la sociedad civil hacia uno de los retos más apremiantes que enfrenta el país: lograr mayor desarrollo con menor desigualdad. El motor para enfrentar el desafío es la movilidad de las personas. Desde la perspectiva de desarrollo humano, este motor permite la ampliación de las opciones de vida (movilidad absoluta) y ayuda a reducir la desigualdad en las oportunidades (movilidad igualadora).
El diagnóstico muestra que México experimentó movilidad absoluta de oportunidades ascendente al inicio del siglo XXI y también una mayor movilidad igualadora entre entidades federativas, municipios e individuos. No obstante, se requieren medidas para que la reducción de las desigualdades lleve a una mayor movilidad absoluta e igualadora de oportunidades y, con ello, a un desarrollo más sostenible e incluyente.
Para ayudar a desencadenar acciones que lleven a consolidar la movilidad de las mexicanas y los mexicanos, este informe señala los retos pendientes en la materia: la integración regional de las entidades federativas, municipios y delegaciones políticas; el ejercicio del gasto público que fomente la igualdad de condiciones entre los individuos en etapas clave de la vida, y el mejoramiento de las condiciones laborales que favorezcan la movilidad a partir del trabajo. La mayor prueba para las reformas nacionales en el marco de la Agenda 2030 apenas comienza, y su reto consiste en la implementación. PNUD acompaña el seguimiento de las políticas públicas que alimentarán la consecución de los ODS con la publicación del Informe sobre Desarrollo Humano México 2016. Desigualdad y movilidad.
El proyecto está en una fase de revisión a fin de determinar, de forma conjunta con la contraparte, su cierre o bien ampliación en términos de alcances, actividades y presupuesto.

Después de un proceso de negociación, SEDESOL ha accedido a que con los recursos remanentes del proyecto (alrededor de 84,000 USD) se haga la actualización de la información del Índice de Desarrollo Humano Municipal (1 informe); la cual, ofrecerá un panorama actualizado del desarrollo humano en los municipios del país, aportando información relevante para las posteriores discusiones y análisis de propuestas de políticas públicas y acciones encaminadas a mejorar el desarrollo regional y humano del país y al logro de los objetivos de la Agenda 2030. Se está en proceso de contratación de la Coordinación del proyecto, así como a la espera de la liberación de algunas bases de datos necesarias para el Informe. Idealmente, se espera que CONEVAL libere los datos de ingreso a nivel municipal en diciembre.
